resources_description: Learn about hearing health, protection, and best practices for maintaining good hearing.
part1_title: Protect Your Ears from Loud Noise
part1_intro: Noise-Induced Hearing Loss (NIHL) is the most common preventable type of permanent hearing loss. It happens when the delicate hair cells in your inner ear are damaged by sounds that are too loud, for too long.
how_loud_description: Sound is measured in decibels (dBA). Prolonged exposure to any noise at or above 85 dBA can cause gradual hearing loss. Louder sounds can cause damage in a much shorter time.
prevent_description: Lower the volume on your personal listening devices (phones, music players). A good rule is the 60/60 rule: listen at no more than 60% of the maximum volume for no more than 60 minutes at a time.
protect_description: Wear hearing protection in loud environments. Earplugs or earmuffs with a Noise Reduction Rating (NRR) can protect your hearing in noisy situations.
plan_description: Be aware of noisy environments before you go. If you're heading to a concert, sporting event, or festival, bring earplugs with you.
provide_rest_description: After exposure to loud noise, give your ears a break. Step outside the noisy venue for 10-15 minutes every hour to allow them to recover.
part2_intro: Your ears are largely self-cleaning. Improper cleaning can cause more harm than good.
dont_swabs: DO NOT insert cotton swabs into your ear canal. This pushes earwax deeper, creating a blockage, and risks scratching the canal or even perforating your eardrum.
dont_candles: DO NOT use ear candles. They are ineffective and pose a serious risk of burns and ear canal blockage from melted wax.
dont_sharp: DO NOT use sharp objects like bobby pins or pen caps to clean your ears.
do_selfclean: DO let your ears clean themselves. The natural migration of skin in the ear canal pushes old earwax out.
do_outer: DO clean the outer ear with a soft washcloth.
do_professional: DO seek professional help if you suspect an earwax blockage. Symptoms include a feeling of fullness, muffled hearing, or ringing in the ear (tinnitus).
part3_intro: Your ears are connected to your body's circulatory and nervous systems.
manage_conditions_description: Conditions like diabetes, high blood pressure, and heart disease can damage the blood vessels in the inner ear. Managing these conditions protects your hearing.
dont_smoke_description: Smoking and vaping can interfere with blood flow to the inner ear and have been linked to a higher risk of hearing loss.
medication_awareness_description: Some medications can damage hearing. These include certain types of antibiotics, chemotherapy drugs, and high doses of aspirin. Ask your doctor about potential effects on your hearing.
part4_intro: Hearing loss is often gradual, making it hard to notice at first.
sign_repeating: Frequently asking others to repeat themselves.
sign_understanding: Difficulty understanding conversations, especially in noisy places.
sign_mumbling: Thinking that other people are mumbling.
sign_volume: Needing to turn up the volume on the TV or radio higher than others prefer.
sign_tinnitus: Ringing, buzzing, or hissing in your ears (tinnitus).
sign_tired: Feeling tired or stressed from the effort of trying to hear.
what_to_do_title: What to Do if You Suspect a Problem:
dont_ignore_description: Untreated hearing loss is linked to social isolation, depression, and an increased risk of cognitive decline and dementia.
get_test_description: This is the most important step. A comprehensive hearing evaluation (audiogram) performed by an audiologist is painless and will precisely measure your hearing ability.
consult_professional_description: An audiologist or ENT specialist (otolaryngologist) can diagnose and treat hearing problems.
sudden_loss_warning: If you experience a sudden, significant drop in hearing in one or both ears, treat it as a medical emergency and see a doctor immediately.
action_baseline: Get a baseline hearing test if you're over 40 or regularly exposed to noise.
action_protect: Use earplugs or earmuffs during loud activities.
action_volume: Keep your personal listening devices at a safe level.
action_hygiene: Clean only your outer ear and avoid putting anything in your ear canal.
action_health: Eat well, exercise, and manage chronic conditions.
action_signs: Pay attention to warning signs of hearing loss and get tested if concerned.
